CAA 112(r) Executive Summary

BHS Acquision, LLC DBA BHS Marketing - Nampa

BHS ACQUISITION (BHS) is a multinational wholesale distributor of chemical products.  As of the date of this submission, the Company operates two (2) distribution warehouses in the United States; only the Nampa facility is subject to Risk Management Program Planning.  This summary describes BHS's Risk Management Program for its Nampa, Idaho, facility.

I.Statement of Senior Management Commitment to Safety

BHS's President drafted a formal "Statement of Corporate Policy on Safety and Environmental Protection".  This statement has been provided to all employees and the Company's public and private emergency responders as evidence of the Company's commitment to safety.  The following excerpt is taken directly from the Corporate Statement:

    "The personal safety and health of each member of BHS's staff is of paramount importance.  As a company, our very existence depends on service to our customers and support from our neighbors.  BHS's reputation for safety in handling chemical products will do much to determine the company's future growth.  Our goals include employee safety and prevention of all hazardous material releases to the environment.  We will maintain a safety and environmental program, which embodies the proper attitudes toward safety and environmental protection on the part of everyone.  This program requires the total cooperation on the part of every employee in all safety, health and environmental matters.

BHS ACQUISITION has specifically authorized designated facility emergency coordinators to "commit any resources necessary to control an incident.  This includes mobilization of other emergency response organizations as well as the purchase of necessary supplies and equipment"."

II.    General Facility Description

BHS ACQUISITION - Nampa, Idaho is located in an industrial area along Interstate-I84, inside the Nampa, ID. city limits.  The site is split into two separate properties

within the industrial area.  The property that provides storage for the RMP chemicals is bounded on three sides by other businesses and factories, and to the east by a large field.  Surrounding uses are industrial.  The closest residence is 0.3 miles away.  There are no at-risk populations (e.g., schools, nursing homes, day-care centers, hospitals, prisons, etc.) located within 0.5 mile of the facility.  The closes environmentally sensitive area is the Deer Flat National Wildlife Refuge, approximately 5.0 miles away.

A.  Description of Primary Activities at Facility

 BHS - Nampa is a warehousing, distribution, packaging and blending facility only.  No manufacturing of chemical products occurs at this facility.  All RMP regulated chemical products are received, stored and delivered to customers in the original closed containers.

B.  Description of Facility Processes

BHS - Nampa engages in the following activities:
--Delivery by truck of chemical products in bulk and non-bulk UN-approved containers,
--Internal movement of chemical products from the receiving area by forklift (or pallet jack( to and from the designated storage area),
--Delivery of chemical products to customers,
--Packaging from large containers into small containers (no RMP chemicals),
--Blending of two or more chemicals into a third chemical.

C.  Description of Products/Quantities Handled at Facility

BHS Nampa from time to time may store two CAA ?112 RMP program chemicals in amounts that exceed threshold planning quantities:  Chlorine gas and Sulfur Dioxide Gas.  The largest container of chlorine gas that might be stored at the facility is a one-ton cylinder.  The largest container of sulfur dioxide gas that might be stored at the facility is a one-ton cylinder.

III.  Accidental Release Prevention Planning at the Facility

A.  Rules and Regulations that Apply to this Facility

Too many federal, state and local environmental safety rules and regulations apply to this facility to detail in this

summary.  The primary legislation affecting chlorine is OSHA's Process Safety Management(PSM) rule.  A chlorine PSM program has been implemented at the facility.  The uniform fire and building codes also apply to this facility and are enforced by the Nampa City Fire Department.  The fire department performs periodic safety inspections of the facility.

The Company has a formal safety-training program designed to meet training requirements promulgated by OSHA, DOT and EPA.  Hazard communication training (OSHA) is the primary method the Company uses to educate employees on the risks associated with these two chemicals.  Emergency response training is performed in accordance with OSHA's HazComm/Hazwoper regulations (29CFR Part1910.120 and 29CFR Part1910.1200).

B.  Internal (Company) Release Prevention Program Requirements

BHS is a member of and has an employee on the Board of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD), It is certified under the NACD's "Product Stewardship / Responsible Distribution" Program.  This program requires member companies to prepare policies and procedures that promote the safe use and handling of chemical products by member companies and also by customers who purchase the chemical products.  BHS has more than 100 policies/procedures that address topics including the storage, handling, and transportation of compressed gases and incident planning for Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide gas (among other BHS - designated "chemicals of concern").

BHS facilities are audited regularly for compliance with all internal and external requirements by BHS environmental staff as well as independent auditors.

IV.  Five-Year Accident History

No accidents or accidental releases involving either of these chemicals have occurred at BHS Nampa facility. 

V.  Emergency Response Program

BHS - Nampa has an emergency response plan that is exercised annually.  The plan is reviewed and updated as often as necessary (e.g., to reflect changes in personnel,

emergency response contractors, etc.).  The facility has contracted with an emergency response contractor (Olympus Technical) to provide assistance with any incidents that cannot be handled by the facility or the fire department.  BHS - Nampa has three on-site emergency coordinators who are trained to manage all incidents that require implementation of the plan.

BHS also maintains a corporate emergency spill response phone number (1-208-249-0730).  The on-call technical support employee is immediately available to provide assistance during an incident.  The on-call staff acts as backup to the on-site emergency coordinators.

VI.  Planned Improvements to Safety Program

BHS is committed to accident prevention and, accordingly, maintains an excellent reputation in the chemical distribution industry.  A primary planned improvement to BHS's safety program is an update of the training materials (e.g., videos and handouts and lesson plans) to meet revised regulatory requirements.

Introduction
BHS ACQUISITION (BHS) is multi-national wholesale distributor of chemical products.  Personnel trained in the safe handling and storage of chemicals, including bulk commodity, non-bulk quantities and compressed gases, operate each BHS branch.

Every BHS branch varies in chemical inventory, equipment and means of chemical handling.  Although every branch is different, the processes for handling chemicals are similar.  Primarily, at the BHS Nampa branch, the covered RMP process is storage only.

Processes Covered
A thorough review of all covered chemicals was conducted in 2004.  An evaluation of process applicability will be conducted prior to the addition of any new covered chemicals to branch inventories.

Section 1.17 of the RMP-Submit Report in Appendix 1 details the covered processes at the Nampa branch and is incorporated by reference.  Due to the day-to-day variance in inventories, the chemicals stored at the Nampa branch have the potential to change, as well as the quantities stored.  For this reason, every quantity listed under column c.3 in Section 1.17 is a maximum inventory amount.  This quantity will be updated prior to any change in the maximum inventory.

Accident

History
No accidents involving covered processes identified in Section 2.0 resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage in the last five years at the Nampa branch.
